description:
Musca vetustissima is a species of fly belonging to the family Muscidae. It is considered one of the oldest known species of true flies, with fossil records dating back to the Eocene epoch, around 50 million years ago.

This fly species is characterized by its typical muscid body shape and features, including a pair of membranous wings, compound eyes, and a proboscis adapted for feeding on a variety of organic materials. The species is believed to have been an important part of ancient ecosystems, potentially playing a role in the decomposition of organic matter and the cycling of nutrients.

While not much is known about the specific ecological niche or behavioral characteristics of Musca vetustissima, its long evolutionary history and persistence over millions of years suggest that it was well-adapted to the environmental conditions of its time. The study of this ancient fly species can provide valuable insights into the evolution and adaptation of dipteran insects over geological timescales.
